moves.1. d4 d5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. e3 c5 4. b3 Nc6 5: This is my usual setup, I've been fairly successful with it for about a year now. I don't study openings much, so I've pretty much just stuck with this one.
moves.7... O-O 8. Nbd2: For a possible e4 push, additional support for a c4 push, or just a developing move.
moves.8... Re8 9. Ne5: This time I chose Ne5, normally here I play 1 of 4 moves, c4, e4, a3, or Ne5.
moves.9... a6 10. f4: Adding additional support to the e5 knight. It does create a hole on e4, but for now I'm controlling that square.
moves.10... Qc7 11. a3: Preventing Nb4 ideas, which, in order to keep my double bishop pair, would force Be2 making it harder to do a kingside attack, which is my plan here.
moves.11... b5 12. dxc5: Also to avoid being forced to retreat my bishop with 12...c4.
moves.12... Bxc5 13. Rf3: Trying to get a kingside attack going, and protecting e3.
moves.13... Bd6: ? Totally missing my next two moves, which allow an easy kingside attack. I would have played something like Be7, protecting the f6-knight.
moves.14... Qxc6 15. Bxf6: Opening his king up for an attack on the g-file.
moves.15... gxf6 16. Bxh7+: For awhile I was planning on Rg1+ Kf8(Kh8 Qg4) Bxh2, with a passed h-pawn and him having a central king. But, then I thought, if he wanted to get checkmated, why not give him the option?
moves.17. Rg3: Limiting his king's maneuverability and threatening Qh5 mate.
moves.17... Kh6: Either this or Bf8 was the only was to stop mate in 1.
moves.18. Qg4: There is now no way to stop a checkmate on the h-file, so my opponent resigned. Thanks for reading, please feel free to comment and rate this annotation and let me know how I did!
